content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It's a good idea, a little challenging to implement but still very doable.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Fun clash, solvable even under Reverse conditions. It took me 6 minutes in Reverse conditions, but should be solvable in under 5 with the statement.
I think Shortest mode should be enabled, that would be fun.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Looks fine to me! I don't know about it being too complex to solve in the timeframe. Getting the distances of directions is easily done with a flag and a regex or a char count function, and then all that's left is to figure out which ones the highest. Neat.
This task poses a considerable level of complexity, which renders it challenging to resolve within the given timeframe of 5 to 10 minutes.

Cases
* Some pairs of cases are the same. Please revise them so that they are similar but different.

* Please change Test 3 so that it requires output of "W" too (no other test requires that output).

* Please change the last validator so that it requires output of "N" too (no other validator requires that output).

Thanks.

Off the top of my head I can think of at least three different ways to identify the coordinates of the crosspoint, and then you just have to measure the number of spaces extending from the four directions from the crosspoint!

Thank you!
I added Shortest mode.
I would alt f4 immediately if I got this one on shortest mode

Really? I never understood why people would treat Shortest mode as scarier than Fastest mode.

If it's a hard clash, then just forget about golfing and see if you can solve it in time. You'll probably end up coming in the top 50% even if your code is ungolfed. And if you happen to finish with spare time, then you can golf it afterwards. ¯\_(ツ)_/¯

Honestly, I find Fastest way scarier, because every second counts. Whereas with shortest, I can usually take it slow.

This problem is long and challenging enough that I would not want to worry about optimizing my approach for code golf, I would rather plan and code a working solution with any approach that come to mind.
